bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Charles Henry May was a New York ophthamologist. He recieved his medical degree from the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University in 1883. He later studied in Europe, specializing in ophthamology and otology. He was on the staff of many New York hospitals and clinics, and he founded the ophthalmological department at Belleveue Hospital in 1914 and served as its director until 1925. Additionally, he maintained a large private practice, developed opthalmological instruments, and contributed to textbooks, reference works, and periodicals.
Source: Doherty, William Brown. "Dr. Charles H. May." Trans Am Ophthalmol Soc 42 (1944): 18.2-22. PubMedCentral.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This small collection includes: May's 1883 thesis, "Statistics of 400 cases of rheumatism at Roosevelt Hospital," from the College of Physicians and Surgeons; an illustrated manuscript on the "Enuncleation with transplantation and reimplantation of eyes," detailing a history of the procedure and May's studies on rabbits; and 31 original illustrations by E. G. Bethke used in the "Manual of the diseases of the eye, for students and general practitioners."
